profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-04-02 14:01:22 -0700.

physdesc.extent: (82 boxes, 17 record cartons, 8 flat boxes, and 4 roll boxes)

did.abstract: The Los Angeles-based environmental group TreePeople is known for promoting environmental awareness and conducting educational outreach programs locally as well as internationally. The collection includes slides, photographs, audiovisual materials, clippings, correspondence, organization files, ephemera, and awards documenting the development and efforts of TreePeople.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Andy Lipkis, President of TreePeople, 2013.

odd.head: UCLA Catalog Record ID
odd.p: UCLA Catalog Record ID: 9973924843606533

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], TreePeople Records (Collection 2180). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: TreePeople, a non-profit environmental organization, was founded by Andy Lipkis in Los Angeles in 1973. Originally called the California Conservation Project (CCP), the group was more commonly referred to as the "TreePeople," and was thus, renamed in 1974. Lipkis established the organization at the age of eighteen following his experiences at a leadership training program in the San Bernardino National forest. After attending the program, Lipkis directed his efforts toward establishing the CCP in order to provide people with environmental education and the opportunity to plant trees.

In 1977 TreePeople established their headquarters in Los Angeles on the grounds of a former fire station. The site was renamed Coldwater Canyon Park, and would later serve as TreePeople's Center for Community Forestry. Since its founding, TreePeople have worked to promote environmental awareness through city-wide tree planting programs, as well as environmental education and training for the local community, and on a global scale. TreePeople's efforts have included disaster-relief work, in addition to initiating significant urban planting projects. These projects include the Million Tree Campaign in 1981, which encouraged the planting of one million trees before the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Olympics; the Martin Luther King Boulevard Memorial Project, where three hundred trees were planted in a single day; and the Big Tree Campaign, an urban-planting project aimed at providing shade to homes, buildings, and large sun-exposed spaces in and around the greater Los Angeles area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of material related to the Los Angeles based environmental organization, TreePeople. The collection includes slides, photographs, audiovisual materials, clippings, correspondence, organization files, ephemera, and awards documenting the development and efforts of TreePeople. The materials represent assorted TreePeople events and programs such as their Urban Forestry program, Million Tree Campaign, King Boulevard Memorial Project, public school outreach, and disaster relief work, among other undertakings.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Organization Files
Press Clippings
Photographic Materials
Awards
Audiovisual Materials

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Interview of Andy Lipkis [oral history transcript] / Jane Collings, interviewer. UCLA Library Center for Oral History Research, 2006-2007.

Environmentalists-California -- Los Angeles -- Archives.
Urban forestry -- California -- Los Angeles -- Citizen participation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of correspondence, notes, articles, and ephemera related to TreePeople's local, national, and international community activities and events. Projects represented include King Boulevard Memorial Project, Million Tree Campaign, Urban Forestry, international tree planting efforts, and school programs, among others. Additionally, there is a small amount of board meeting minutes and annual reports; reports and proposals created by TreePeople and other organizations; promotional brochures, mailers, and cards, and a small amount of ephemera. There is no specific arrangement to the series; the series may contain duplicative material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of newspaper and magazine articles about TreePeople and their activities and organizational development. The bulk of the clippings/articles are from both local and national newspapers and magazines, such as LA Daily News and Los Angeles Times. Also includes a small amount of pieces that were not clipped from their original publication. The writings represent Andy Lipkis' founding of the organization and his role as director; the organization's community education efforts; disaster relief work; and involvement in significant projects, such as the million tree campaign in Los Angeles prior to the 1984 Olympic Games. Additionally, there are a small number of clippings on the topic of trees as well as general environmental issues. The series is likely to include duplicative materials and there is no specific arrangement.

did.unittitle: Los Angeles Times Home magazine article related to Tree People
Magazine publications containing articles about TreePeople (5 folders)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: May contain duplicates found elsewhere in the collection. Mixture of articles about TreePeople or general environmental issues.

did.unittitle: Press clippings related to Andy Lipkis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of photographs, slides, negatives, and proof sheets documenting TreePeople and their activities and events. The materials represent TreePeople staff and volunteers; urban, mountain and citizen forestry work, disaster relief work, fruit tree distribution project, educational outreach and programs, such as Generation Earth, and special events, such as the Marina Freeway Run, Martin Luther King Boulevard Memorial Project, and Harvest Moon. Additionally, there are a small number of photographs/snapshots featuring Andy Lipkis and notable individuals such as Mayor Tom Bradley, Vice President Al Gore, Gregory Peck, and Betty White, among others.

The photographs are mostly snapshots, with a small amount of professional shots. The slides are 35mm. There is no specific arrangement; however, many of the images have been grouped by like content, which is indicated by the file title or in the notes. Many of the slides are unidentified and are labeled "slide binder." Slides have been removed from binders for preservation purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of national, state, county and city awards, honors, and commendations presented to Andy Lipkis and/or TreePeople for their continuing efforts to promote environmental awareness. Included are a mix of certificates, plaques, and three-dimensional objects. There is no specific arrangement to the series.

did.unittitle: City of Los Angeles Earth Day award
Los Angeles city and county awards
Los Angeles city and county awards
Los Angeles City Department of Recreation and Parks award

odd.head: General note
odd.p: With signed letter from George Bush.

did.unittitle: Van Nuys Sherman Oaks Ecology Council award

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of audio cassettes, DVDs, and assorted video formats. The materials document television interviews and news coverage of TreePeople's environmental efforts, as well as local, national, and international community activities and events, such as the King Boulevard Memorial Project, Million Tree Campaign, Harvest Moon fundraising events, and other outreach programs. There is no specific arrangement to the series.
